poem:
The New Tillage

The earth shifts beneath our feet—  
not as our fathers knew,  
plows carving ancient soil.  
The sun now glares, relentless,  
on vines clinging to tradition.  
Stellios, you tend dreams anew,  
thread roots through change  
lest the harvest grow thin,  
yet hope, like grape,  
must ripen in altered sun.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘We cannot do it the way our fathers did’: farmers across Europe struggle to adapt to the climate crisis “I’m not ready to change jobs,” says Stellios Boutaris, a wine producer with vineyards in Naoussa and Amyndeon in northern Greece, as well as on the island of Santorini. But, he adds, “we cannot do it the way our fathers did.” Boutaris is determined to keep producing in the region and keep the family business going". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
